parameters.description: Algorithm used in this f-set. Constraints: - If algorithm is not set with milenage or custom_type_a, OP and r1-r5 and c1-c5 constants cannot be set. - If algorithm is not set with tuak, TOP and keccak parameters cannot be set. - If algorithm is set with milenage or custom_type_a, OP must be set. - If algorithm is set with tuak, TOP must be set. - If deployment is HSM-only, algorithm can only be set to: milenage. - custom_type_a can only be set for those customers that have the corresponding (MRD) Market Requesting Development license granted

c1 constant value. Hexadecimal string with 32 characteres length. Only applicable to Milenage algorithm. If this attribute is left empty, the applied default value is \"00000000000000000000000000000000\"

c2 constant value. Hexadecimal string with 32 characters length. Only applicable to Milenage algorithm. If this attribute is left empty, the applied default value is \"00000000000000000000000000000001\"

c3 constant value. Hexadecimal string with 32 characteres length. Only applicable to Milenage algorithm. If this attribute is left empty, the applied default value is \"00000000000000000000000000000002\"

c4 constant value. Hexadecimal string with 32 characteres length. Only applicable to Milenage algorithm. If this attribute is left empty, the applied default value is \"00000000000000000000000000000004\"

r1 constant value. Decimal string from 0 To 127. Example: \"5\" Only applicable to Milenage algorithm. If this attribute is left empty, the applied default value is 64
r2 constant value. Decimal string from 0 To 127. Example: \"9\" Only applicable to Milenage algorithm. If this attribute is left empty, the applied default value is 0
r3 constant value. Decimal string from 0 To 127. Example: \"20\" Only applicable to Milenage algorithm. If this attribute is left empty, the applied default value is 32
r4 constant value. Decimal string from 0 To 127. Example: \"69\" Only applicable to Milenage algorithm. If this attribute is left empty, the applied default value is 64
r5 constant value. Decimal string from 0 To 127. Example: \"125\" Only applicable to Milenage algorithm. If this attribute is left empty, the applied default value is 96

Pattern (regular expression according to the ECMA-262 dialect) representing the NF domain names allowed to access the NF instance. The absence of this attribute indicates that any NF domain is allowed to access the NF instance. If this attribute is present in the nf-service, the attribute from the nf-service shall prevail. If this attribute is not present and it is not present either in the nf-service, it indicates that there is no corresponding restriction to access the service instance.

Type of the NFs allowed to access the NF instance. If this attribute is present in NF Service, the attribute from NF Service shall prevail. If this attribute is present in NF Profile but is absent in NF Service, the attribute in NF Profile shall be applied. If this attribute is not present neither in NF Profile nor in NF Service, it indicates that there is no corresponding restriction to access the NF instance.

S-NSSAI of the allowed slices to access the NF instance. The absence of this attribute indicates that any slice is allowed to access the NF instance. If this attribute is present in the nf-service, the attribute from the nf-service shall prevail. If this attribute is not present and it is not present either in the nf-service, it indicates that there is no corresponding restriction to access the service instance.
parameters.constraints: No NSSAI (empty array)

parameters.description: Value of the last requested status of the UDM NF in the NRF. Setting this value triggers a request to the NRF to register, deregister or suspend the UDM NF. When set to \"registered\" or \"suspended\", that shall be the value of the NFStatus parameter in the registration/update request towards NRF. When set to \"deregistered\", the UDM NF profile data shall be deleted from NRF. Acting on this attribute does not have any influence on how UDM NF manages incoming/outgoing or OAM traffic. It is just NFstatus published in NRF. Whenever UDM NF enters in total unavailability state (NO UDR available) UDM sets autommatically this attribute to value \"suspended\" and it cannot be changed to \"registered\" meanwhile total unavailability state persists. This value is not necessarily the current status value of the UDM NF in the NRF (note that there are other means to change the UDM NF status in the NRF).

parameters.description: Value of the last requested status of the NF in the NRF. Setting this value triggers a request to the NRF to register or suspend the NF. When set to \"registered\" or \"suspended\", that shall be the value of the NFStatus parameter in the registration/update request towards NRF. When set to \"deregistered\" (value only allowed when NF administrative-state is not supported), the Network Function's registration profile data shall be deleted from NRF. This value is not necessarily the current status value of the NF in the NRF (note that there are other means to change the NF status in the NRF).

parameters.description: Value of the last requested status of the HSS NF in the NRF. Setting this value triggers a request to the NRF to register or suspend the HSS NF. It can be set to \"registered\" or \"suspended\", and that must be the value of the NFStatus parameter in the registration/update request towards NRF. Modifying this attribute does not have any influence on how HSS NF manages incoming/outgoing or OAM traffic. It is just NFstatus published in NRF. Whenever HSS NF enters in total unavailability state (NO UDR available) HSS sets autommatically this attribute to value \"suspended\" and it cannot be changed to \"registered\" while the total unavailability state persists. This value is not necessarily the current status value of the HSS NF in the NRF (note that there are other means to change the HSS NF status in the NRF).

This attribute indicates the charging characteristics for the EPS User. It is an integer corresponding to the needed bit mask value according to S6a Interface Description in HSS-EPC, and Telecommunication management; Charging management; Charging Data Record (CDR) parameter description (3GPP TS 32.298). For instance, to indicate the following:- Octet1: 0A - Octet2: 00Then the value of the parameter is 10, that is, the decimal value for 000A. The order of the octets is different from the one described in S6a Interface Description in HSS-EPC for the 3GPP-Charging-Characteristics AVP, as the value in the example is equivalent to 0A00 for this AVP.

This attribute indicates whether the current eps-apn-configuration instance can be deleted. Before deleting the the instance, HSS-EPC checks this attribute: if its value is true, the instance can be deleted; if its value is false, the instance cannot be deleted. When it is not defined, the deletion will be allowed if the generic can-be-deleted NF level parameter is set to true. Before setting this attribute value to true, ensure that the eps-apn-configuration is a context no longer used by any EPS user.

This attribute is the Allocation Retention and Priority (ARP) bearer level QoS parameter. ARP is an indicator of the priority of allocation and retention for the corresponding APN configuration.
This attribute defines whether the default bearer can get resources already assigned to another bearer with a lower priority level.
This attribute defines whether the default bearer can lose the resources assigned to it, to admit a pre-emption capable bearer with a higher priority level.

This attribute is the QoS Class Identifier (QCI) bearer level QoS parameter. It identifies a set of IP-CAN specific QoS parameters that define the authorized QoS, excluding the applicable bit rates for the IP-CAN bearer or service flow (refer to Policy and charging control architecture (3GPP TS 23.203)).
This attribute is the static identity of the PDN GW node in the format of an FQDN.

It identifies the PDN GW host. The domain name shall have the format of: <topon | topoff>.<single-label-interface-name>.<canonical-node-name> For more information, refer to Domain Name System Procedures; Stage 3 (3GPP TS 29.303).
It identifies the PDN GW realm. The realm name shall have the format of: epc.mnc.mcc.3gppnetwork.org <MNC> and <MCC> are digits. The character $ is used as separator, it is forbidden in the fields.

HSS-EPC general configuration parameters

Indicates whether any eps-apn-configuration instances in the node can be deleted. Before deleting an eps-apn-configuration instance, first HSS-EPC checks the can-be-delete individual level parameter in the eps-apn-configuration object. In case it is not defined, this one applies. If its value is FALSE, deleting the eps-apn-configuration instance is not allowed.
parameters.constraints: recommendation is keep to false so they cannot be deleted by mistake

parameters.description: The attribute is used to configure which type of service data are consolidated in the external database. Each bit represents one service type: Bit 0: Circuit Switch Packet Switch (CSPS) Bit 1: reserved Bit 2: reserved Bit 3: reserved Bit 4: AuC Bit 5~15: reserved, The meaning of each bit is aligned with the imsiMask attribute defined in mscidentifies in UDC LDAP schema.
parameters.dependencies: depending on solution consolidation in UDR

parameters.description: This attribute represents the maximum number of request messages that can be sent in diameter interfaces without having a response simultaneously at any moment.

Indicates whether the eps-profile instances in the node can be deleted. Before deleting an eps-profile instance, first HSS-EPC checks can-be-deleted individual level parameter in the eps-profile object. In case it is not defined, this one applies. If its value is FALSE, deleting the eps-profile instance is not allowed.
parameters.constraints: recommendation is keep to false so they cannot be deleted by mistake

parameters.description: This attribute indicates if the Roaming Area of EPC users is matched with either MME diameter Identity, MME Realm or both.

parameters.constraints: recommendation is keep to false so they cannot be deleted by mistake

This attribute contains a bit mask where each bit when set to 1 indicates a restriction. If this attribute is not configured, all accesses are not restricted. This attribute contains a bit mask where each bit when set to 1 indicates a restriction. If this attribute is not configured, all accesses are not restricted. This attribute identifies the roaming service profile

A Zone Code Set is a profile of zone-codes to be applied in this PLMN. The interpretation of the zone code combination is done in MME and it is operator dependent. It might be used for service restrictions, special charging per area or any other specific purpose
This attribute indicates whether the current EPS zone Code Set can be deleted.

HSS-EPC Profile object contains information about EPS user data that can be common for many EPS users. It is possible to create, to retrieve, to modify and to delete such kind of objects. parameters.description: Value of the last requested status of the NF in the NRF. Setting this value triggers a request to the NRF to register or suspend the NF. When set to \"registered\" or \"suspended\", that shall be the value of the NFStatus parameter in the registration/update request towards NRF. When set to \"deregistered\" (value only allowed when NF administrative-state is not supported), the Network Function's registration profile data shall be deleted from NRF. This value is not necessarily the current status value of the NF in the NRF (note that there are other means to change the NF status in the NRF).

parameters.description: The ss7 is an abstraction of the entire Signaling System number 7 configuration.
Loadshare by Calling Party Address. Defines whether SCCP loadshares by CgPA GT translations for outgoing messages originated by old-interface users.
The m3ua is an abstraction of MTP-L3 User Adaptation layer (M3UA).
Common configuration data for Application Server (AS).
Defines the way the parameter Concerned Destination is handled in the DUPU message.
Defines DUPU handling compliance.
The identifier of the AS profile.

The frequency of sending MTP-STATUS indication to user during congestion. For example if it is set to 2, M3UA sends MTP-STATUS indication for every second User Part message related to the congested DPC.
Defines the way the MTP-RESUME indication is sent to user. This parameter impacts local-asp associations only. In case of local-ipsp this parameter is ignored.

Time to wait for the last message on the other remote SP to be delivered until send of new messages. This parameter is used to avoid missequencing. Timer is started when SP enters or leaves Active state for a certain AS. Zero value means sending new messages immediately or discard if there are no active SP.

Time to wait for Notify message with Active state before moving AS to Active state. This value is only of interest when notify-behavior is set to resume-after-notify. Zero value means to wait forever.

Timer to control the period when an M3UA destination is considered congested. Timer starts after receiving a SCON message with non-zero congestion status. Zero value means that timer is not started. It is not recommended to set the timer to zero, because congestion may never cease.
Time spent to try to make a failover. During this time AS is able to go to Active state if SP serving it go to Active state.
Label for free use.

Size of the buffer that is used during failover procedure. Failover is the procedure of rerouting of signaling traffic to an alternate Server Process (SP). During failover procedure messages are stored into failover buffer. Zero value means that messages are discarded and not stored during failover procedure.

Application Server (AS) used on the local side. AS - a logical entity serving a specific Routing Key. The local AS is served by a Server Processes (local IPSP or local ASP), which is normally actively processing traffic. A local AS must be referred by one Local SP (local IPSP or local ASP).
Identifier of AS profile, which contains common configuration data to define behavior of local-as.

The identifier of the local AS. All remote-as and local-as IDs must be unique and share the same range of values. For example, it is not possible to create local-as and remote-as with IDs 1 simultaneously.

Network Appearance (NA) identifies MTP node in M3UA protocol. A local reference that together with a Signaling Point Code uniquely identifies an SS7 node by indicating the specific SS7 network to which it belongs. The NA identifies an SS7 network context to logically separate the signaling traffic. The zero value means that NA parameter is not used and is not included in the messages.

Identifier of node, which associates the local-as with signaling-network and a local-signaling-point. The code of the referred local-signaling-point is also used as originating point code (OPC) in Routing Key if not overridden in any child rk-grouping.
parameters.dependencies: id of the node-id of the local-signaling-point within Signaling-network

parameters.description: Identifier of a remote-as that this local-as exchanges traffic with. A local-as serving local-ipsp must refer to a remote-as. Parameter is not used in ASP-SGP configuration. It means that local-as served by local-asp must not refer to a remote-as.

Set of SS7 parameters, uniquely defining the range of signaling traffic to be handled by local-as. All rk-grouping instances must have a unique set of parameters (local-spc, dpc) and associated with parent local-as node-id. If routing-context-handling parameter in remote-ipsp or remote-sgp related to parent local-as is not set to rfc-4666-compliant, local-as.node-id is treated as 0.
List of allowed identifiers of remote-signaling-point instances. Empty list means that any destination point code is allowed.
parameters.dependencies: code value of the remote-signaling-point within signaling-network

parameters.description: The identifier of the RK grouping.
The Local Signaling Point Code of the M3UA user which resides on local-as. If set to -1, Local Signaling Point Code is inherited from parent local-as (local-as/node-id/code).
Label for free use.

The identifier of Local SP in local-as. Local SP can be configured to process signaling traffic within more than one local-as. In that case, routing-context together with SCTP Association uniquely define the range of signaling traffic associated with each local-as.
The identifier of the Routing Context.
Label for free use.
Label for free use.

Application Server Process - a process instance of a local AS connected with instance of SG. Local ASP uses the services of a Signaling Gateway (SG). It contains an SCTP Endpoint and can be configured to process signaling traffic within more than one local AS.

The identifier of the local ASP. All local-ipsp and local-asp IDs must be unique and share the same range of values. For example, it is not possible to create local-asp and local-ipsp with IDs 1 simultaneously.

Identifiers of local ASes that this local ASP serves for. If local-asp refers to more than one local-as, then routing-context must be configured under local-as instances and must be unique for each of them.
A process instance of a Remote Signaling Gateway (SG).

Application Server Process identifier. If asp-identifier-handling is set to asp-id-from-aspup asp-identifier points to the pair of local Server Process (SP) and this remote SP. If asp-identifier-handling is set to no-asp-id the parameter points to the local SP this remote SP is connected to. It is possible to set equal asp-identifier for different remote SPs, but only if they relate to the same local SP. Non-zero asp-identifier is included in ASPUP (ASPUP ACK) message. Zero value means that asp-identifier is not included in ASPUP message.
Defines which ASP Identifier local or remote Server Process (SP) returns in ASPUP ACK message. ASPUP messages are sent by client, ASPUP ACK messages are sent by server.

The identifier of the remote SGP. All remote-ipsp and remote-sgp IDs must be unique and share the same range of values. For example, it is not possible to create remote-sgp and remote-ipsp with IDs 1 simultaneously.

Congestion level which is set in case of local congestion (reception of CONGESTION notification). In case of association congestion egress user messages with priority less than local-congestion-level are discarded.

The parameter decreases threshold of user message discarding in case of congestion. Messages with priority less than 'Actual Congestion Level - message-discard-level-shift' are discarded. If expression result is negative then all messages are passed. Zero value means that no shifting is applied and messages are discarded according to the standard.
Defines how Network Appearance of local AS that is served by connected local SP is treated.
List of remote IP Addresses. The set of remote addresses together with the remote-port-number defines the remote SCTP endpoint being used.
The port number of the remote-asp. Zero value must be set when remote-asp is configured as client. It means that remote port is defined at reception of COMMUNICATION UP notification from remote side.
The identifier of the remote SG that this remote-sgp serves for.
Identifier of remote-sp-profile, which contains common configuration data to define behavior of SP.

List of Routing Contexts which identify a local-as that is served by connected local SP. If this list is empty it means that Routing Context is not used. If remote-ipsp or remote-sgp refers to more than one local-as, then routing-context must be configured under local-as instances.

Defines how ASPAC and DATA messages are processed if Routing Context is not present. Defines whether Routing Context can be transmitted in outgoing M3UA messages and how it must be handled in incoming M3UA messages for this remote SP. This parameter is needed to allow communication with Ericsson M3UA implementation that do not support Routing Context.
The identifier of Routing Context under the local-as. Routing Context must be unique for local ASes referred from parent local SP.
The identifier of the local-as. local-as is one from the local-as list in parent local SP.

Defines how traffic is load shared between different remote SPs. This parameter is used if several remote-ipsp instances that serve the same remote-as or several remote-sgp instances that serve the same remote SG exist. Load sharing is only made between remote SPs with the highest priority. So it is possible that remote SP is active but is not used to share traffic since its priority is less than the highest one among all active remote SPs. Such remote SPs are in stand-by mode. All remote SPs with the same priority must be of the same type.
Defines responsibility for association establishment.
Label for free use.
Identifier of a local-sctp-endpoint that is used for association establishment.
Label for free use.

IP Server Process - a process instance of a local-as connected with instance of remote-as. Local IPSP uses M3UA in a point-to-point fashion. It contains an SCTP Endpoint and can be configured to process signaling traffic within more than one local-as.

The identifier of the local IPSP. All local-ipsp and local-asp IDs must be unique and share the same range of values. For example, it is not possible to create local-ipsp and local-asp with IDs 1 simultaneously.

Identifiers of local-as instances that this local-ipsp serves for. If local-ipsp refers to more than one local-as, then routing-context must be configured under local-as instances and must be unique for each of them. Each remote-as referred by local-ipsp through child remote-ipsp must be referred by at least one local-as referred by the local-ipsp.
A remote IP Server Process - a process instance of a remote AS. Remote IPSP uses M3UA in a point-to-point fashion.

Application Server Process identifier. If asp-identifier-handling is set to asp-id-from-aspup asp-identifier points to the pair of local Server Process (SP) and this remote SP. If asp-identifier-handling is set to no-asp-id the parameter points to the local SP this remote SP is connected to. It is possible to set equal asp-identifier for different remote SPs, but only if they relate to the same local SP. Non-zero asp-identifier is included in ASPUP (ASPUP ACK) message. Zero value means that asp-identifier is not included in ASPUP message.
Defines which ASP Identifier local or remote Server Process (SP) returns in ASPUP ACK message. ASPUP messages are sent by client, ASPUP ACK messages are sent by server.
This parameter defines the type of ASPSM and ASPTM messaging between local-ipsp and remote-ipsp. ASPSM Messages - ASP State Maintenance Messages. ASPTM Messages - ASP Traffic Maintenance Messages.

The identifier of the remote IPSP. All remote-ipsp and remote-sgp IDs must be unique and share the same range of values. For example, it is not possible to create remote-ipsp and remote-sgp with IDs 1 simultaneously.

Congestion level which is set in case of local congestion (reception of CONGESTION notification). In case of association congestion egress user messages with priority less than local-congestion-level are discarded.

The parameter decreases threshold of user message discarding in case of congestion. Messages with priority less than 'Actual Congestion Level - message-discard-level-shift' are discarded. If expression result is negative then all messages are passed. Zero value means that no shifting is applied and messages are discarded according to the standard.
Defines how Network Appearance of local AS that is served by connected local SP is treated.

List of remote IP Addresses. The set of remote addresses together with the remote-port-number defines the server remote SCTP endpoint being used. If addresses are not-specified, remote-ipsp acts as SCTP client.

Identifiers of remote ASes that this remote IPSP serves for. If remote-ipsp refers to more than one remote-as then each of these remote-as instances must have non-zero routing-context and must include the same number of identifiers of routing-context instances of connected local-as instances.

ASP identifier of remote-ipsp. This parameter is also used for dynamic identification (when remote-addresses are not specified and remote-port-number is zero for the remote-ipsp), as follows: - non-zero value available only when asp-identifier-handling equals to no-asp-id and it means that the association is identified by remote-asp-id. Therefore this value must match with the ASP identifier parameter received in ASPUP from remote IPSP, otherwise ASPUP is answered with ERROR; - zero value means, that the association is identified by asp-identifier. It is forbidden to set equal (except zero value) remote-asp-id for different remote-ipsp instances, if they connect to local-ipsp instances that reside on the same local-sctp-endpoint. remote-asp-id can be equal to asp-identifier in remote-sgp only if their parent local-ipsp and local ASP uses different local-sctp-endpoint instances.

The port number of the remote-ipsp. If remote-address is not specified for remote-ipsp, remote port also must be set to zero. It means that remote port is defined at reception of COMMUNICATION UP notification from remote side.
Identifier of remote-sp-profile, which contains common configuration data to define behavior of SP.

List of Routing Contexts which identify a local-as that is served by connected local SP. If this list is empty it means that Routing Context is not used. If remote-ipsp or remote-sgp refers to more than one local-as, then routing-context must be configured under local-as instances.

Defines how ASPAC and DATA messages are processed if Routing Context is not present. Defines whether Routing Context can be transmitted in outgoing M3UA messages and how it must be handled in incoming M3UA messages for this remote SP. This parameter is needed to allow communication with Ericsson M3UA implementation that do not support Routing Context.
The identifier of Routing Context under the local-as. Routing Context must be unique for local ASes referred from parent local SP.
The identifier of the local-as. local-as is one from the local-as list in parent local SP.
parameters.dependencies: id of the local-as within m3ua

parameters.description: Defines how traffic is load shared between different remote SPs. This parameter is used if several remote-ipsp instances that serve the same remote-as or several remote-sgp instances that serve the same remote SG exist. Load sharing is only made between remote SPs with the highest priority. So it is possible that remote SP is active but is not used to share traffic since its priority is less than the highest one among all active remote SPs. Such remote SPs are in stand-by mode. All remote SPs with the same priority must be of the same type.
Defines responsibility for association establishment.
Label for free use.
Identifier of a local SCTP Endpoint that is used for association establishment.
Label for free use.

Represents a local SCTP Endpoint. SCTP Endpoint is the logical sender/receiver of SCTP packets. Local Server Processes (SPs) are mapped to local SCTP Endpoint. It is possible to share local SCTP Endpoint between several local SPs.
The identifier of the local SCTP Endpoint.
Defines which type of addresses is used.

List of local addresses. The set of local addresses together with the port-number defines the server local SCTP endpoint being used. If addresses are not-specified, local primary network address is used. If addresses has value '0.0.0.0' or '::', or '0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0', that is considered as any address. In this case, all IP addresses of secondary network are used regardless of ip family.
The IP address of the local endpoint.
VPN Name is the text string, that defines network in which this IP Address will be placed. If vpn-name is empty, VPN will not be used for the IP address
The port number of the local SCTP Endpoint. Local SCTP Endpoints with the same port cannot be created.
Label for free use.

Application Server (AS) used on the remote side. AS - a logical entity serving a specific Routing Key. One Routing Key is used for both directions of traffic. So the Routing Key used on remote-as is the mirrored Routing Key on local AS. The remote-as is served by a IP Server Process (remote-ipsp), which is normally actively processing traffic. remote-as must be referred by one remote-ipsp. Exactly one local-as must refer to each remote-as at a time.
Identifier of AS profile, which contains common configuration data to define behavior of remote-as.

The identifier of the remote AS. All remote-as and local-as IDs must be unique and share the same range of values. For example, it is not possible to create local-as and remote-as with IDs 1 simultaneously.

Uniquely identifies the Routing Key of the remote-as. Must be defined if there are several remote ASes served by the same remote-ipsp. A zero value means that routing-context is not used for this remote-as. This parameter must be unique among all remote-as instances. Note: this parameter is not used in case of remote-ipsp serving this remote-as have exchange-mode set to single.
Label for free use.
Common configuration data for remote Server Process (SP).
Number of attempts to send the ASSOCIATE request message. Zero value means sending infinte number of ASSOCIATE request.
The parameter defines the number of times M3UA attempts to send the DAUD. Zero value means sending infinite number of DAUD messages.

Defines handling of Destination Restricted (DRST) messages. RFC compliant behavior - DRST messages are handled on receiving. Ericsson Sigtran compliant behavior - DRST messages are never sent and answered with error (ERR) on receiving.
Defines if heartbeat procedure is activated or not.
The identifier of the remote SP profile.

Defines max number of affected Point Codes allowed in one DAUD message. If there are more affected PCs than this max, multiple DAUDs are sent. Zero value means no limitation on the number of affected PCs in DAUD.

Defines handling of notify (NTFY) messages. RFC compliant behavior - NTFY messages are sent and handled on receiving. Ericsson Sigtran compliant behavior - NTFY messages are never sent and ignored on receiving. If ntfy-support is set to e-sigtran-compliant, AS profile.notifyBehavior must be set to resume-after-aspac-ack.
Time to wait for the acknowledgement of a message before considering an error. It must be greater than the time a message spends to reach the most distant destination, be processed and return.

Time to wait for the COMMUNICATION UP notification before considering association establishment attempt failed. It must be greater than the time a message spends to reach the most distant destination, be processed, and return.
Timer for Audit procedure. This is the time to wait to send/resend DAUD messages towards the SGP to audit the state of SS7 destinations.

Time to wait for ASPIA ACK before considering association removed during reconfiguration inactive. When the timer is expired the impacted association is closed even if no acknowledgement for association deactivation is received. Applicable only for remote-sgp with sctp-type equal to server/client-peer and remote-ipsp with configured IP addresses. Zero value means that an association can be deactivated upon the reception of acknowledgments from the remote side or notification from SCTP level only. If timer-reconfig is set to 0 the value of timer-deactivation is ignored.

Timer is used for the heartbeat procedures. Heartbeat Sending Procedure: every time any message is sent towards remote SP, timerHb is started. If it expires without sending a message to remote SP, a BEAT message is encoded and sent. In this way local M3UA peer informs that it is alive. Heartbeat Receiving Procedure is meant to detect at any time whether remote SP is alive. Every time any message is received from remote peer Heartbeat Receiving Timer (2 * timer-hb) is started. If it expires, remote peer is considered to be DOWN. If the local process is configured as client, after the expiration of Heartbeat Receiving Timer makes an attempt to recover association by sending ASPUP.

Time delay between Automatic Reconnection procedures. It is started when SCTP association establishment fails assoc-establishment-attempts times in a row. When timer-rec expires, new attempts are performed assoc-establishment-attempts times.

Time between resending of ASPUP and ASPAC messages after failed association activation attempt. Timer starts infinite number of times until association is activated. If timerAck expires during ASP Up or ASP Active procedures, timer42 is started. ASPUP or ASPAC request messages are resent after expiration of timer42.

Defines the use of Traffic Mode Type (TMT). RFC compliant behavior - TMT is sent in ASPAC and ASPAC ACK messages. TMT is checked in incoming messages and ERR is sent in case of mismatch with the configured TMT. Ericsson Sigtran compliant behavior - TMT is never sent in ASPAC and ASPAC ACK messages. TMT is not checked in incoming messages.
Label for free use.
Indicates whether SCCP removes Importance parameter from the messages.
Signaling network configuration.
Defines the number of congestion levels for Network.
Specifies how a Global Title (GT) shall be converted. A gt-converter can be used by both shared-gt-translator and gt-translator in all nodes in the network.
The identifier of gt-converter.
Specifies a new value of the nature-of-address or that it is the same as in the source gt-translator.
The number of first digits to be removed from the number-series of the source gt-translator. This field is only used if the number-series-rule has the wildcard symbol '*' at the end.

Part of GT. String of 1 - 18 digits, where each digit is 0 - 9, A, B, C, D, E and F. The maximum number of digits that are meaningful in the network depends on the Numbering Plan. Wildcard symbol "!" can be used in number-series to indicate that it should have the same value as in source GT Number Series. Wildcard symbol "*" represents the part of Number Series in source GT which is obtained by means of cutting several first digits of the source GT Number Series. The number of first Number Series digits to be removed (cut) is controlled by number-of-digits-to-remove. pattern: ([0-9A-F]*\*?)|(!) E.g. 123A*
Specifies a new value of the numbering-plan or that it is the same as in the source gt-translator.
Specifies a new value of the translation-type or that it is the same as in the source gt-translator. Reserved value -1 means Not used. Reserved value -3 means Same as source GT.
Label for free use.

Defines how M3UA sets priority bits in SIO (Service Information Octet) field in the messages. Used only if the Network Indicator of this node is set to 0 or 1 (International network), ignored otherwise.
Identifies the Signaling Network uniquely within the SS7.

Specifies if International screening is enabled or disabled. If International screening is enabled, presence of international significance is checked in the Calling Party Address of the message relayed to an international network.
Node with Local Signaling Point.

Local Signaling Point Code. The allowed range for this parameter depends on the network-standard: 0-16383 (ITU|ETSI) 0-65535 (TTC) 0-16777215 (ANSI|CHINA) Local Signaling Point Code must not be changed
Controls the usage of the timer timer-status-information. SCCP starts the timer upon MTP-RESUME indication receipt.
Priority of general messages that the SCCP generates except SST, IT and RLSD.
Defines if SCCP allows 1111 filler at the end of Global Title (GT).

Defines a Global Title translation and the Address Information (Number Series). gt-transator contains 1, 2, 4, 8 or 16 gt-destination. All gt-translator instances that relate to the same local-signaling-point must have a unique combination of translation-type, number-series, numbering-plan and nature-of-address.
Represents a result of a GT translation.

Reference to GT Converter. Defines if a Global Title (GT) shall be converted upon translation. Pattern for GT, which is modified, is represented in parent gt-translator instance. If both replacement-gt-id and gt-converter are present, replacement-gt is used at first and then converting rule.
parameters.dependencies: id of the gt-converter within signaling-network

parameters.description: Identifies the gt-destination uniquely within gt-translator.

Reference to replacement-gt. Defines the GT which replaces a source GT in a message if the translation points out to the destination. It is only possible to have a reference to replacement-gt instance only if sap attribute refers to local-sap or remote-sap instance. If both replacement-gt-id and gt-converter are present, replacement-gt is used at first and then converting rule.

Reference to SCCP destination. The possible destinations: - If only single gt-destination that relates to parent gt-translator: any another local-signaling-point, remote-signaling-point, local-sap or remote-sap; - If several gt-destination instances that relate to parent gt-translator: local-signaling-point, remote-signaling-point, local-sap that relate to the same signaling-network or remote-sap that relates to the same local-signaling-point.
Identifies the gt-translator uniquely within local-signaling-point.

Controls loadsharing between GT Destinations. The load-share-indicator requires more than one configured gt-destination. When there is only one gt-destination, loadsharing can't be activated despite the parameter's value.

Nature of address (NA) - defines the type of number contained in the Global Title (GT). -2 Wildcard -1 Not Used 0 Unknown 1 Subscriber number 2 National use 3 National significant number 4 International number 5-127 Spare When GT translation is performed, the priority of GT rule with particular value in a subfield is higher than the priority of GT rule with 'Wildcard' (-2) in this subfield. If the value is set to 'Not Used' (-1), then any of gt-destination child instances can refer to gt-converter instance which nature-of-address value is not set to -3.

Number series (NS) - part of GT which contains the actual GT digits. These include enough of the most significant portion of the actual address digits to identify the destination node. String of 1 - 18 digits, where each digit is 0 - 9, A, B, C, D, E and F. The maximum number of digits that are meaningful in the network depends on the Numbering Plan. NS subfield of GT may contain asterisk ('*') and ('?') wildcards. '*' represents any number of digits, '?' represents a single digit. When GT translation is performed, the priority of GT rule with particular value in a subfield is higher than the priority of GT rule with '*' or with '?' in this subfield. pattern: ([0-9A-F]*\\*?[0-9A-F]*)|([0-9A-F]*\\?*) E.g. 123AB 123*56 1234* 123A??

Numbering Plan (NP) - specifies a numbering plan that the address information follows. When GT translation is performed, the priority of GT rule with particular value in a subfield is higher than the priority of GT rule with wildcard value in this subfield. If the value is set to not-used, then any of gt-destination child instances can refer to gt-converter instance which numbering-plan-rule value is not set to same-as-source-gt. numbering-plan can be used only if translation-type is not equal to -1.
Reference to child gt-destination that is defined as primary destination for the GT in load-sharing.
A setting for the Routing Indicator. If set to change-to-route-on-ssn, the Routing Indicator is changed to 'Route on SSN'.

Reference to child gt-destination that is defined as secondary destination for the GT in load-sharing. The parameter must be set if the number of children gt-destination is more than 1. This attribute cannot have the same value as primary-gt-destination.
A setting for the Routing Indicator. If set to change-to-route-on-ssn, the Routing Indicator is changed to 'Route on SSN'.
SPC - part of GT present only for TTC standard and when value of translation-type equals to 6.
Subsystem number - part of GT present only for TTC standard and when value of translation-type equals to 6.

Translation type (TT) - directs the message to the appropriate translator if set to 0-254. -2 Wildcard -1 Not used Wildcard option represents all translators. When GT translation is performed, the priority of GT rule with particular value in a subfield is higher than the priority of GT rule with 'Wildcard' (-2) in this subfield. If the value is set to 'Not used' (-1), then any of gt-destination child instances can refer to gt-converter instance which translation-type-rule value is not set to -3. translation-type must always be set for ANSI network standard. It means that 'Not used' (-1) value cannot be used for ANSI network.
Label for free use.

The hop counter for SCLC (SCCP connection-less control). Parameter value will be decreased by one for each performed GT translation on the way to the end destination. If the counter decrement results in the value of zero in no end destination node, the SCCP initiates the appropriate error procedure.
Defines if Importance parameter is added to messages relayed from ANSI to non-ANSI network.
Represents a local SCCP service access point. The Sub System Number (SSN) identifies a SCCP user within a node identified by a Point Code (PC) within a network.

Defines whether OPC is added to Calling Party Address (CgPA) or not. When the SCCP receives an incoming message (UDT, UDTS, XUDT, XUDTS, LUDT, LUDTS, CR) with CgPA where the Routing Indicator indicates route on SSN but without an SPC present, the SCCP can modify the CgPA in the resulting primitive towards the user. The OPC from the routing label is injected into the CgPA in the correct place.

Defines whether DPC is removed from Called Party Address (CdPA) or not. When the SCCP receives a request from user (N-UNITDATA request or N-CONNECT request) where the CdPA contains an SPC and the Routing Indicator indicates route on SSN the SCCP can remove the SPC in the CdPA in the resulting message towards a remote destination.

Controls the content of the CgPA for an outgoing message originated by the user only. These are only valid for messages sent to the network as the result of the reception of a primitive from the user. Messages generated by the SCCP itself are not be affected. For TRANSPARENT value for ANSI network standard SSN with value 0 is added to CgPA, when it has been missed and route on SSN is used.

Defines whether OPC is added to CgPA and DPC is added to CdPA or not. When the SCCP receives an incoming message (UDT, UDTS, XUDT, XUDTS, LUDT, LUDTS, CR), SCCP modifies the CgPA, if present, for the corresponding user primitive. The OPC in the routing label is added to the CgPA just before the address indicator. The length indicator of the CgPA is adjusted. When the SCCP receives an incoming message (UDT, UDTS, XUDT, XUDTS, LUDT, LUDTS, CR, CREF, CC), SCCP modifies the CdPA, if present, for the corresponding user primitive. The DPC in the routing label is added to the CdPA just before the address indicator. The length indicator of the CdPA is adjusted. When the SCCP receives a user primitive (N-UNITDATA request or N-CONNECT request) the CdPA and CgPA are presumed to contain extra SPCs as described above. The SPCs are not present in the peer-to-peer message. When the SCCP receives a user primitive where the CdPA does not contain an SPC and the Routing Indicator indicates route on SSN the extra SPC is used as DPC in the routing label. If there is an SPC in the address (in addition to the extra) this SPC is used as DPC in the routing label if the routing indicator indicatesroute on SSN. For outgoing messages, if a GTT has been performed successfully, the resulting SPC is used in the routing label. If the user does not use the node ID interface, the SPC before CgPA may be used to select the correct local node. The added SPC is always three octets long regardless of standard.
Controls whether to remove SSN from CgPA or not. SSN is deleted from CgPA in the case when SCCP sends message to the user and SSN in the CgPA is zero. Parameter is applicable for ANSI standard only.

Defines whether to add CgPA and SPC to user interface or not. When the SCCP receives an incoming message (CR or UNITDATA), SCCP inserts the new created CgPA, if absent, for the corresponding user primitive. In this case, the OPC in the routing label is added to the CgPA, SSN is taken from CdPA and the length indicator of the CgPA is adjusted. When the SCCP receives an incoming message, SCCP modifies the CdPA, if present, for the corresponding user primitive. In this case, the DPC in the routing label is added to the CdPA and the length indicator of the CdPA is adjusted.
The identifier of the local-sap.
Label for free use.
Message priority for SST, an SCMG message (SCCP Management message). Parameter is used when a SST message is transferred from the SCCP.

Specifies if the most significant bit (MSB) of address indicator is used. Parameter indicates whether the MSB of the address indicator in the Called Party Address or Calling Party Address is used or not. This is an option applicable for national networks. For international networks the variable is to be set to 0, but for ANSI it is to be set to 1.
Defines if MTI parameter is added to message relayed in ANSI network upon message change procedure. MTI - Message Type Interworking.
Identifies the local signaling node uniquely within the physical node.
Determines whether or not this node is designated for traffic of any SCCP user other than TCAP. If used, at least one local-sap has to be configured for this node.
Determines whether or not this node is designated for TCAP traffic. If used, at least one local-sap has to be configured for this node.
Determines whether or not this node is designated for SRP traffic. If used, at least one remote-sap has to be configured for this node.
Defines whether SCCP inserts a specific SMI value in outgoing messages or not. Note: the Subsystem Multiplicity Indicator (SMI) is always passed through for incoming messages.
Specifies whether to allow remote broadcast or not.
Represents a remote SCCP service access point.
Reference to remote-signaling-point.
The Sub System Number (SSN) identifies a SCCP user within a node identified by a Point Code (PC).
Label for free use.
Used for replacement Global Title value. Global title contains translation-type, numbering-plan, nature-of-address and number-series.
Identifies the replacement-gt uniquely within local-signaling-point.

Nature of address (NA) - defines the type of number contained in the Global Title (GT). -3 Same as source GT -1 Not Used 0 Unknown 1 Subscriber number 2 National use 3 National significant number 4 International number 5-127 Spare If 'Same as source' GT (-3) value is used for nature-of-address, the same value must be used for number-series and numbering-plan.

Number series (NS) - part of GT which contains the actual GT digits. These include enough of the most significant portion of the actual address digits to identify the destination node. Digit string of 1 - 18 digits, where each digit is 0 - 9, A, B, C, D, E and F. The maximum number of digits that are meaningful in the network depends on the numbering-plan. If 'Same as source' GT (!) digit is used for number-series, the same value must be used for numbering-plan and nature-of-address. pattern: ([0-9A-F]*)|(!) E.g. 123A

Specifies a Numbering Plan (NP) that the address information follows. numbering-plan can be used only if translation-type is not equal to -1. If same-as-source-gt value is used for numbering-plan, the same value must be used for number-series and nature-of-address.

Translation type (TT) - directs the message to the appropriate translator if set to 0-254. Special value (-1): Not used translation-type must always be set for ANSI network standard. It means that 'Not used' (-1) value cannot be used for ANSI network.
Label for free use.
Controls when to send the Subsystem Prohibited (SSP) message.
Controls when to send the Subsystem Status Test (SST) message.

Specifies how (X/L)UDTS are constructed from a (X/L)UDT. An (X/L)UDTS ((Extended/Long) Unitdata Service) is a returned message of the sent (X/L)UDT ((Extended/Long) Unitdata). It can be constructed out of an (X/L)UDT by swapping either pointer or data of addresses (called or calling party addresses).

Defines interval when RSLM or RLM can not be increased. RLM - MTP Restriction Level. RSLM - MTP Restriction Sub-Level. The timer is started once an MTP-STATUS indication reported congestion. Any subsequent congestion raise by MTP-STATUS indication will be ignored until the timer expires.

Delay until SCCP considers remote SCCP node residing on DPC and all SCCP users over it Unavailable. The timer is only started when SCCP can not audit the status of remote SCCP destinations with SST message (that is if sst-sending parameter is set to do-not-initiate-sst-messages). The timer will be started when an MTP-STATUS indication with cause differs from congestion is received. The timer is handled per remote destination. When the timer expires, the DPC will be regarded as allowed.

Delay for decrementing the remote SSN congestion level and for decrementing CLS. The timer is started when an Subsystem Congested (SSC) is received from a remote node with congested Subsystem Number (SSN) or if the remote SCCP nodal congestion level (CLS) does not reach 0 during the process when the timer expired. The timer is stopped when the remote SSN congestion level is 0 or CLS is 0. Must be zero for ANSI standard: only for compatibility with ITU/TTC.

Delay for decreasing the RLM and RSLM after congestion has abated. The timer is started or restarted once an MTP-STATUS indication reports congestion. If the timer expires, SCCP will reduce RSLM or RLM.

Defines time interval to wait for receipt of last segments for SCCP Connection-less (CL) messages. The timer is started when the first CL message in sequence arrives. The timer is stopped when the reassembly procedure is finished or the sequence is broken.

Timer is used in Subsystem Status test procedure. The timer is started when an MTP-RESUME indication (for a previously inaccessible signaling point) or Subsystem Prohibited (SSP) SCCP management message has been received. The timer is stopped when an SSA SCCP management message for the subsystem has been received.
Controls the usage of timer-congestion when SSC is received. The timer is used for the decay of remote SSN congestion levels and remote SCCP nodal congestion levels.
Label for free use.
The Network Indicator is used for discrimination of messages between different networks. Network Indicator must not be changed.
Holds the Remote Point Code of the remote node that the local node shall be able to reach.

The maximum allowed size of the Signaling Information Field (SIF) for connectionless SCCP messages. This value is used by SCCP to trigger message segmentation. Connectionless SCCP messages are: UDT, XUDT and LUDT.
Remote Signaling Point Code. The allowed range for this parameter depends on the network-standard: 0-16383 (ITU|ETSI) 0-16777215 (ANSI|CHINA) 0-65535 (TTC)
Controls whether SCMG (SCCP Management Procedures) messages are broadcasted to the remote SPC.

Controls the SCCP ERR messages format. New format of the ERR message contains a pointer to an optional part of the message. Setting this parameter to 1 is needed to communicate with a destination that do not use standard format of ERR message.
This parameter defines the type of segmented SCCP message: LUDT or XUDT. This is valid if user's message size is greater than cl-segmentation-limit and the cl-segmentation-limit is greater than 272.
Label for free use.
A list of Subsystem Numbers (SSNs) to be used in network snapshot configuration
The value represents the Subsystem Number (SSN) - identifier of SCCP application within the network.
Label for free use.

Defines a Global Title translation and the Address Information (Number Series). shared-gt-translator contains 1, 2, 4, 8 or 16 shared-gt-destination. All shared-gt-translator instances that relate to the same signaling-network must have a unique combination of translation-type, number-series, numbering-plan and nature-of-address.
Identifies the shared-gt-translator uniquely within signaling-network.

Controls loadsharing between GT Destinations. The load-share-indicator requires more than one configured gt-destination. When there is only one gt-destination, loadsharing can't be activated despite the parameter's value.

Nature of address (NA) - defines the type of number contained in the Global Title (GT). -2 Wildcard -1 Not Used 0 Unknown 1 Subscriber number 2 National use 3 National significant number 4 International number 5-127 Spare When GT translation is performed, the priority of GT rule with particular value in a subfield is higher than the priority of GT rule with 'Wildcard' (-2) in this subfield. If the value is set to 'Not Used' (-1), then any of gt-destination child instances can refer to gt-converter instance which nature-of-address value is not set to -3.

Number series (NS) - part of GT which contains the actual GT digits. These include enough of the most significant portion of the actual address digits to identify the destination node. String of 1 - 18 digits, where each digit is 0 - 9, A, B, C, D, E and F. The maximum number of digits that are meaningful in the network depends on the Numbering Plan. NS subfield of GT may contain asterisk ('*') and ('?') wildcards. '*' represents any number of digits, '?' represents a single digit. When GT translation is performed, the priority of GT rule with particular value in a subfield is higher than the priority of GT rule with '*' or with '?' in this subfield. pattern: ([0-9A-F]*\\*?[0-9A-F]*)|([0-9A-F]*\\?*) E.g. 123AB 123*56 1234* 123A??

Numbering Plan (NP) - specifies a numbering plan that the address information follows. When GT translation is performed, the priority of GT rule with particular value in a subfield is higher than the priority of GT rule with wildcard value in this subfield. If the value is set to not-used, then any of gt-destination child instances can refer to gt-converter instance which numbering-plan-rule value is not set to same-as-source-gt. numbering-plan can be used only if translation-type is not equal to -1.
Reference to child shared-gt-destination that is defined as primary destination for the GT in load-sharing.
A setting for the Routing Indicator. If set to change-to-route-on-ssn, the Routing Indicator is changed to 'Route on SSN'.

Reference to child shared-gt-destination that is defined as secondary destination for the GT in load-sharing. The parameter must be set if the number of children shared-gt-destination is more than 1. This attribute cannot have the same value as primary-gt-destination.
A setting for the Routing Indicator. If set to change-to-route-on-ssn, the Routing Indicator is changed to 'Route on SSN'.
Represents a result of a GT translation.

Reference to GT Converter. Defines if a Global Title (GT) shall be converted upon translation. Pattern for GT, which is modified, is represented in parent gt-translator instance. If both replacement-gt-id and gt-converter are present, replacement-gt is used at first and then converting rule.
Identifies the shared-gt-destination uniquely within shared-gt-translator.

Reference to shared-replacement-gt. Defines the GT which replaces a source GT in a message if the translation points out to the destination. It is only possible to have a reference to shared-replacement-gt instance only if sap attribute refers to local-sap or remote-sap instance. If both replacement-gt-id and gt-converter are present, shared-replacement-gt is used at first and then converting rule.

Reference to SCCP destination. The possible destinations: - shared-remote-sap or remote-signaling-point that relates to the same signaling-network; - If shared-gt-destination is referenced as primary it can refer to local-sap or to local-signaling-point that relates to the same signaling-network or to any local-signaling-point if only primary shared-gt-destination exists.
SPC - part of GT present only for TTC standard and when value of translation-type equals to 6.
Subsystem number - part of GT present only for TTC standard and when value of translation-type equals to 6.

Translation type (TT) - directs the message to the appropriate translator if set to 0-254. -2 Wildcard -1 Not used Wildcard option represents all translators. When GT translation is performed, the priority of GT rule with particular value in a subfield is higher than the priority of GT rule with 'Wildcard' (-2) in this subfield. If the value is set to 'Not used' (-1), then any of gt-destination child instances can refer to gt-converter instance which translation-type-rule value is not set to -3. translation-type must always be set for ANSI network standard. It means that 'Not used' (-1) value cannot be used for ANSI network.
Label for free use.
Represents a remote SCCP service access point common for all nodes.
Reference to remote-signaling-point.

Identifies the shared-replacement-gt uniquely within signaling-network.

Number series (NS) - part of GT which contains the actual GT digits. These include enough of the most significant portion of the actual address digits to identify the destination node. Digit string of 1 - 18 digits, where each digit is 0 - 9, A, B, C, D, E and F. The maximum number of digits that are meaningful in the network depends on the numbering-plan. If 'Same as source' GT (!) digit is used for number-series, the same value must be used for numbering-plan and nature-of-address. pattern: ([0-9A-F]*)|(!) E.g. 123A

Specifies a Numbering Plan (NP) that the address information follows. numbering-plan can be used only if translation-type is not equal to -1. If same-as-source-gt value is used for numbering-plan, the same value must be used for number-series and nature-of-address.

Translation type (TT) - directs the message to the appropriate translator if set to 0-254. Special value (-1): Not used translation-type must always be set for ANSI network standard. It means that 'Not used' (-1) value cannot be used for ANSI network.
Label for free use.
The spare-bits in the SIO for a national network. These bits can optionally be treated as a congestion priority or as spare.
Label for free use.
An abstraction of Transaction Capabilities Application Part for ETSI, ITU, TTC standards (TCAP EIT).
The maximum number of concurrent operations per dialogue that can be invoked by a Local TCAP user. Allowed to be increased only.

The maximum number of dialogues per subsystem. Caution: The value of this parameter must be chosen so that the memory for the dialogues does not exceed the system memory capacity. Exceeding the system capacity will cause failure because there is not enough free system memory. Allowed to be increased only.
The maximum number of dialogues per second to be aborted. The value is applied when it is needed to abort many dialogues due to user disconnect/unbind.
Maximum number of concurrent TCAP subsystems (including subsystems with individual number of dialogues). Allowed to be increased only.

The maximum number of messages that are sent from the message buffer towards TCAP user in one burst. The value is applied when TCAP recovers user traffic which was previously buffered due to different reasons.
The maximum number of concurrent user applications that can be bound to each subsystem. Allowed to be increased only.
Represents a subsystem which has individual maximum number of dialogues. Allowed to be created or modified only.
The identifier of tcap-eit-ssn-ssn-indiv-max-dia.

The maximum number of dialogues per subsystem. Caution: The value of this parameter must be chosen so that the memory for the dialogues does not exceed the system memory capacity. Exceeding the system capacity will cause failure because there is not enough free system memory.
The reference to the signaling-network under which the subsystem is configured for loadsharing.
The reference to the subsystem configured for loadsharing.
Subsystem for which a loadsharing of calling party addresses for outgoing dialogues is supported.
The identifier of tcap-eit-ssn-loadshare.
Defines how to loadshare calling party addresses for outgoing dialogues.
The reference to the signaling-network under which the subsystem is configured for loadsharing.
The reference to the subsystem configured for loadsharing.

Timer to be used when reading SCCP related parameters including Global Titles at intervals. Zero value means that timer is not used. All SCCP configuration parameters including Global Titles section are read in one attempt.
